description: Smart phones and tablets broadcast information that anyone can use to discover where you live, where you work and the places you go. Free WiFi networks allow attackers to intercept and alter your communications. This presentation shows a series of live demonstrations showing exactly how this is done and how easy it is. We show in real time what information the broadcasts your mobile devices send 24/7 reveal about you, and how attackers use fake WiFi access points and man-in-the-middle attacks to capture passwords, subvert VPNs, and install malicious software. The root causes of these issues are explored, and we present solutions, both simple and complex, to safeguard your data, your privacy and your identity.
name: Gone in 60 Milliseconds: Mobile devices, free WiFi and your data.

description:
As dev and test most of us have been in the situation where a security bug is found by a customer and we find ourselves asking – 'how did we miss that'. With a focus on the challenges facing development and test teams, we'll explore some of the issues and solutions that can help improve your SDLC.

Speaker: Sean Wilson is an IT Security Analyst at Canadian Bank Note
how_to_find_us: World Exchange Plaza, Find the 100 Queen Street Building, Take the elevator to the 5th floor. Be sure to be there before 6:00 PM as the elevators stop working then.
name: Another Bug? Secure Software Development Lifecycle

description:
Social Engineering from the ground up. From creation of the attack vectors in the Social Engineering Toolkit, to execution, to defense in ASP.Net. We shall oversee what defense mechanisms or techniques exist to defend against certain Social Engineering Attacks. The take away: ASP.Net Techniques and modules, SET Experience and techniques. 

Speaker: Joel Hebert - MVP

Joel Hebert is a Software Architect who resides in Ottawa. He is passionate about Security and Architecture. He is a seven time ASP.Net MVP and is one of the User Group Leaders in Ottawa. He would like to share his knowledge of Social Engineering, Web Application Defences and Continuous Audit with you to allow you to think about the modern attack vectors that are present.
how_to_find_us: World Exchange Plaza, Find the 100 Queen Street Building, Take the elevator to the 5th floor. Be there before 6:00 PM as the elevators stop working then.
name: Social Engineering - ASP.Net Defense Systems

description:
Social Engineering from the ground up. From creation of the attack vectors in the Social Engineering Toolkit, to execution, to defense in ASP.Net. We shall oversee what defense mechanisms or techniques exist to defend against certain Social Engineering Attacks. The take away: ASP.Net Techniques and modules, SET Experience and techniques. 

Speaker: Joel Hebert - MVP

Joel Hebert is a Software Architect who resides in Ottawa. He is passionate about Security and Architecture. He is a seven time ASP.Net MVP and is one of the User Group Leaders in Ottawa. He would like to share his knowledge of Social Engineering, Web Application Defences and Continuous Audit with you to allow you to think about the modern attack vectors that are present.
name: Social Engineering - ASP.Net Defence Systems - Kanata Edition

description:
Many organizations are evaluating and migrating toward cloud computing solutions.  In 2013, some the key challenges pertain to security and interoperability.  Open cloud standards can help manage risks, while fostering efficient solution delivery.

Steven Woodward shares updates from numerous international cloud standards related organizations. In Canada, he leads several of the cloud computing initiatives in both the private and public sectors.  This includes being one of the founding board members of the Cloud Security Alliance Canadian Chapter.

Steven describes key cloud ecosystems models; highlighting where security considerations fit, along with different perspectives on interoperability.  Several real-life scenarios will be used, highlighting cloud concepts, security, interoperability and the impacts these can have on commitments (functionality, costs, time-to-value and quality).  Service Agreements and Service Level Agreements will also be addressed to identify where you may find security and interoperability considerations specified in the contracts.

The presentation is designed to be interactive and will include some group activities to generate discussions and identify practical solutions.

Attendees of the presentation will leave with a better understanding of cloud security and interoperability considerations, plus be aware of reference material and models that help address those challenges.


Speaker: Steven Woodward, CEO, Cloud Perspectives

Steven Woodward is CEO founder of Cloud Perspectives and is the leader of the NIST (National Institute of Standards for Technology) Cloud Carrier and Cloud Auditor Sub-Groups within the Cloud Computing Reference Architecture. 

He is a leading contributor to NIST, TM Forum, Object Management Group Cloud Standards Customer Council, Canadian Cloud Council, IEEE and the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Joint Collaboration Activity working groups. 

Steven represents the Canadian Advanced Technology Alliance at the Shared Services Canada Architecture Advisory Committee and is influencing the Canadian Federal Government Cloud Computing Strategy. Steven is also one of the founding directors at the Canadian Chapter of the Cloud Security Alliance (CSA). 

In addition to cloud standards and best practices guides, he authored the “Cloud Computing Solution Measurement” chapter in the 2012 CRC Press published book, “The IFPUG Guide to IT and Software Measurement.” 

A frequent international instructor, keynote presenter and leader, he continues to help establish realistic roadmaps, plans, contracts, SLAs and governance practices for cloud computing. Recent and planned speaking engagements includes: National Science Foundation – Arlington Virginia, AFEI – Washington, ISMA - Rio de Janeiro, IEEE – Cyprus, Florida International University, Florida Atlantic University, itSMF – Ottawa, ISACA CACS – Las Vegas, TM Forum – Nice, BFPUG – Brasilia and OWASP in Ottawa and Los Angeles.
how_to_find_us: World Exchange Plaza, Find the 100 Queen Street Building, Take the elevator to the 5th floor. Be there before 6:00 PM as the elevators stop working then.
name: Cloud Computing – Security and Interoperability Perspectives

description:
Speaker: Sherif Koussa

Description:

Let's face it: security is often an afterthought for development teams, often left until the end of the development life cycle and just before going to production. This is particularly an issue when it comes to application security. Deadlines are looming with no time or resources left for any disruptions, especially not another security bug. Teams will more often than not simply do nothing, while even the most proactive ones will only order a quick vulnerability scan to ensure that there are no obvious security problems. Days, months and even years may pass without an incident, until the ugly face of hackers show up and a security incident happens. With exploits making the news headlines daily, it is pretty clear that neither attackers nor security bugs are going anywhere. It is also clear that whatever we are doing today as far as application security (or the lack of) is not working.

If the above sounds familiar then you will need to attend this presentation. You will understand what you will need to focus on first, what to do to achieve systematic results out of your application security assessments, open-source tools to use, static code analysis and manual code review techniques and finally the main components of an effective security code review process.
how_to_find_us: World Exchange Plaza, Find the 100 Queen Street Building, Take the elevator to the 5th floor. Be there before 6:00 PM as the elevators stop working then.
name: The 6-Points Strategy to Get Your Applications in Security Shape

description:
Speaker: Nadeem Douba

Abstract: To a normal human, hacking things like browsers and software seems like black voodoo magic. Even people in IT security struggle with the basic understanding of how a buffer overflow works. This workshop aims to demystify the art of exploiting vulnerabilities in binary software and equips you with the tools to pwn software on your own! We'll cover the following topics:

1. A brief introduction to Assembly

2. A brief overview of the Linux Stack

3. Our Toolkit for Exploit Development

4. Controlling the Instruction Pointer  

     a. Classic BOF (no strings attached)  

     b. ROP till' you drop (Defeating NX)  

     c. Where am I? (Defeating ASLR)   

     d. Silence the Canary (Defeating Stack Canaries)

5. Advanced Topics to Research

Students are expected to bring a laptop as this workshop is hands-on. The following tools/software is required:

- A VMWare image of 32-bit Kali Linux (download: http://cdimage.kali.org/kali-1.0.9a/kali-linux-1.0.9a-i386.iso)

- PEDA (https://github.com/longld/peda)- Metasploit (apt-get install metasploit)- Shelln00b (apt-get install shellnoob)

- ROPGadget (git clone  https://github.com/0vercl0k/rp)

- IDA Demo 6.6 for Linux (http://out7.hex-rays.com/files/idademo66_linux.tgz)

- build-essential: apt-get install build-essential

- wine: apt-get install wine

Students are encouraged to work in groups so encourage your friends to come along!

WARNING: We are in no way responsible for any hair loss during the course of this workshop. Successfully exploiting software may result in unusual happy dance behaviour.
how_to_find_us: World Exchange Plaza, Find the 100 Queen Street Building, Take the elevator to the 5th floor. Be there before 6:00 PM as the elevators stop working then.
name: ROP It Like It's Hot: A 101 on BOFs, ROPs, and Shellcode Development on Linux

description:
Abstract:

Application Security is focused on the identification, remediation and prevention of Security Vulnerabilities in application software.  There are several topics in the Application Security space that help achieve this objective.  Software Security Assurance is the process by which development organizations ensure that their software is free from security vulnerabilities.  Application Assessment, Vulnerability Management and Vulnerability Remediation are some of the key activities that help organizations develop secure software.

This talk will focus on Static Code Analysis, a critical Application Assessment practice in any effective Application Security initiative.  We will explore key topics in Static Code Analysis (from an application security perspective).  We will illustrate best practices for integrating Static Code Analysis into a Software Security Assurance program resulting in a Secure Software Development Life Cycle.  Finally we will demonstrate the effective use of Static Code Analysis as part of your everyday SDLC.

Speaker:    

Paul Kitor, CISSP is a Senior Solution Architect focused on Fortify technologies within the Enterprise Security Products business unit at HP.  In this role, Mr. Kitor acts as the primary technical advisor to develop and position a broad range of Application Security solutions with customers.  In his responsibilities, Paul provides technical leadership and technical depth concerning HP Fortify solutions.  He works closely with customers and partners in assisting them meet their strategic Application Security initiatives and also provides thought leadership and insight regarding the ever changing global threat landscape. He possesses 20+ years of Information Security experience in the areas of Application Architecture, Java/C/C++ Development, Agile SDLC, and Application Security.  Prior to joining HP Canada, Paul worked as a Solution Architect at Oracle, BEA Systems, and Borland Software he also lead Java development teams at Airmiles.ca and Points.com.
name: Static Code Analysis a Cornerstone of Application Security

description:
Abstract: Malware triage is am important function in any mature incident response program; the process of quickly analyzing potentially malicious files or URLs to determine if your organization had exposure. But what if you don't have an incident response program? What if you are just setting one up? What if you don't have the tools you need to perform your analysis? With the current offering of free online tools, the right mindset, a web browser, and a notepad may be all you need.  

Welcome to crowdsourced malware triage!

This talk will explore the power of the crowd to perform triage analysis of malware and get the answers you need. Each online will tool will be demonstrated as we walk through the analysis of a popular exploit kit.

Speaker: Sergei Frankoff is a malware researcher and the Director of Threat Intelligence at Ara Labs (http://aralabs.com/). He is a strong advocate of an open source approach to malware analysis tools and malware intelligence sharing. You can find him on Twitter @herrcore.
name: Crowd-sourced Malware Triage

description:
Abstract: 

This whirlwind tour of the field of malware analysis will aim to demonstrate some useful reverse engineering techniques using a case study approach.  We'll walk through the analysis of a real ransomware sample from initial triage and basic analysis to the reverse engineering and code analysis techniques that were used to break the crypto.  The results of the analysis will be used to write a standalone decryptor that can be used to unlock files held ransom by the malware campaign.  Along the way the audience will learn some of the tricks of the trade such as how to create an analysis environment, using binary disassembly tools, debugging tricks, defeating weak crypto/encoding schemes and anti-reversing techniques.

Speaker Bio:

Karim Nathoo is a freelance computer security consultant providing specialized security services to both government and private sector clients. Karim has extensive experience in high assurance ethical hacking, malware analysis, incident response and security product evaluation, including the application of binary code analysis and reverse engineering. Karim has delivered professional services for international clients in Asia, Europe, Canada and the United States. Karim has performed security assurance and engineering engagements for organizations such as Apple, Microsoft, France Telecom, Cloakware Corporation, Creative Labs, Motorola, Verizon, Nokia, Philips Semiconductor, SONY BMG, SUN Microsystems, QNX Software Systems and numerous Canadian and US Government agencies.
name: Breaking Malware - A Case Study (Kanata)

description:
While Google, PayPal and eBay use bug bounty programs to get access to security talent and offer incentives to security researchers to work with them and not against; critics accuse companies of trying to gain access to talent cheaply, critics point to other issues in the bug bounty programs model like coverage and thoroughness.

OWASP’s June event at the Library will be new and different, again! This time we are having a lively and informative debate about bug bounty and white hat programs!  What’s that you say?      

The evening will start with a brief lesson about what bug bounty and white hat programs are, followed by an introduction of our guest panelists and our moderator.  Then the debating begins!

Guest Panelists:

1- Prof. Anil Somayaji - Computer Science Dept. @ Carleton University 

2- Clayton Smith - Application Security @ Shopify 

3- Eric Carter - Project Leader and IT Security Analyst @ Elections Canada

4- Phillipe Arteau:  Security Researcher and seasoned application security advisor working for large financial institution.

Moderator: Tanya Janca - OWASP Ottawa’s resident security enthusiast and library partnership coordinator

You can RSVP on meetup if you would like, but we need you to RSVP with the library, here: http://biblioottawalibrary.ca/en/node/24005

Location: The Main branch of the Ottawa Public Library - 120 Metcalfe (@ Laurier) Main auditorium

Please note that you must register through the library: http://biblioottawalibrary.ca/en/node/24005
name: Debate: Bug Bounty Programs - Optimization or Laziness?

description:
Abstract: We'll discuss a high level approach to vulnerability research to find new vulnerabilities in products and its role in the development process as well as high assurance Penetration Testing. We will quickly dispense with the slide decks and dive into the demonstration of the identification of vulnerabilities in a simple custom network service-based application that will follow the process of 

•  Input identification and input modeling 

•  fuzzing the identified input points

•  identifying the problem,

•  reverse engineering the code to identify the root case 

•  identify mitigation strategies 

• assess exploitability 

If there is time in the session we will also develop a simple exploit to demonstrate the vulnerability and show some of the issues facing exploit developers. This topic will be continued at our follow up OWASP talk in September on Weaponing Exploits.

Speaker: Mike Sues
name: Vulnerability Hunting

description:
Speaker: Mike Sues - Rigel Kent Security

Abstract: The goal of this talk is a continuation from our previous OWASP talk introducing you to the identification and analysis of new vulnerabilities, to cover some of the realities of developing exploits for operational use in the field, especially when little information is known or available by the attacker about the target's environment. We do not present this so you can go out and now own the world, but to understand how more sophisticated threat agents think and go about their development to enable and sustain exploitation/access. We will discuss means by which the operational risk to the attacker can be mitigated by building features and resiliency into the exploit code that is typically not seen in freely-available exploit code. Moreover, we will also cover other forms of operational risk of that can expose the attacker to compromise themselves and how they are able to handle this risk. These features and risks will be discussed in the context of exploit tools and software backdoors analyzed from known compromises and campaigns.
name: Weaponizing Exploits

description:
Agenda:

5:30 - 6:00 PM: Pizza + Networking:

6:00 - 6:50 PM: Securing Wordpress - Shawn Hooper: WordPress powers approximately 25% of all sites on the web.  This makes it a large target for hackers.  Learn about the functions build into the WordPress framework to help counter some of the most popular forms of attacks, as well as some best practices for securing your WordPress installations.

Speaker: Shawn Hooper a WordPress core contributor, and active speaker in the WordPress community.  He has been developing web applications since the mid-90s, and working heavily in WordPress since about 2011, on projects for government, corporate, and non-profit clients in both Canada and United States.  Shawn is now CTO at Actionable Books, overseeing product development that includes several WordPress projects. 

7:00 - 7:50  PM: Breaking Malware - A Case Study - Karim Nathoo

This whirlwind tour of the field of malware analysis will aim to demonstrate some useful reverse engineering techniques using a case study approach.  We'll walk through the analysis of a real ransomware sample from initial triage and basic analysis to the reverse engineering and code analysis techniques that were used to break the crypto.  The results of the analysis will be used to write a standalone decryptor that can be used to unlock files held ransom by the malware campaign.  Along the way the audience will learn some of the tricks of the trade such as how to create an analysis environment, using binary disassembly tools, debugging tricks, defeating weak crypto/encoding schemes and anti-reversing techniques.

Speaker: Karim Nathoo is a freelance computer security consultant providing specialized security services to both government and private sector clients. Karim has extensive experience in high assurance ethical hacking, malware analysis, incident response and security product evaluation, including the application of binary code analysis and reverse engineering. Karim has delivered professional services for international clients in Asia, Europe, Canada and the United States. Karim has performed security assurance and engineering engagements for organizations such as Apple, Microsoft, France Telecom, Cloakware Corporation, Creative Labs, Motorola, Verizon, Nokia, Philips Semiconductor, SONY BMG, SUN Microsystems, QNX Software Systems and numerous Canadian and US Government agencies.
name: October Meeting

description:
Agenda:

5:00 - 5:45 PM: Pizza + Networking:

5:45 - 6:45 PM: Dirty Breach Secrets - Dave Ockwell-Jenner

Anthem. US Office of Personnel Management. Sabre. United Airlines. We hear about big breaches with increasing frequency, but what's it like to actually be front-and-centre in the middle of one? We'll peek under the hood to see just what goes on in those first 24-72 hours after detection, and beyond through the battle with the attacker, managing 'management', and to eventual resolution and lessons learned. The talk will focus on some of Dave's experiences with such a situation, battling an Advanced Persistent Threat now believed to be part of the largest cyber espionage campaign to date. More importantly, we will examine some of the things needed to be prepared for such an event, and how you can come out smiling

Speaker: Dave Ockwell-Jenner is a Cyber Security Architect with SITA, the world's leading specialist in air transport communications and information technology. He has an extensive background in technology and security, from building one of the Internet's first web sites to designing and securing solutions for global telecommunications companies. Dave has co-authored training material for the SANS Institute and is a regular presenter on security topics at conferences and community events. In his role at SITA, Dave leads the Security Threat and Operational Risk Management (STORM) group which focuses on preventing, detecting and neutralizing security threats. He is a GIAC certified Forensic Analyst and has led many security incident investigations from commodity attacks to advanced capability campaigns.
name: November Meeting

description:
5:00 - 5:30 PM: Networking and Pizza

5:30 - 6:15: Michael Bennett - Team Lead - DDoS Strike

Abstract: More and more DDoS attacks are targeting the Application Layer in order to knock your sites and services offline. These attacks need far less horsepower to drive results and often target weaknesses in an application and its defences in order to be effective. While there are solutions available to protect your application, they can only do so much and often are misconfigured for an application. In this presentation we’ll talk about common misconfigurations that we come across during our DDoS testing, as well as some web application design considerations that help some DDoS defences to be more effective.

6:15 PM - 6:30 PM: Lightening Talk:  XCOLD Information Leaks -  Rick Mitchell, Security Analyst

Abstract: Have you heard about XCOLD Information Leaks? In this lightning talk we'll quickly review how an innocent seeming entry in Firefox's release notes lead an IT Security Professional to analyze a mechanism aimed at aiding developers, resulting in the development of a new OWASP ZAP Passive detection rule.
name: January Meetup

description:
5:00 - 5:30 PM: Networking and Pizza

5:30 - 6:15 PM: Reducing threat risk surface with better intelligence gathering - Michel Juneau-Katsuya 

Too often performing a Threat and Risk Assessment (TRA) is performed in a very mechanical way. To the point where now people give less and less importance to it. But assessing accurately your vulnerability, based on a good and appropriate intelligence assessment, gives you a chance to pin point the real threats, the real vulnerability. This session will discussion the challenges and crucial omissions made in performing TRA. And no...you don’t need to work for CSIS or CSEC to performed a good, intelligence based TRA.

Would that work?  I know I'd like to see that talk, personally.  Do you think our audience would?

Speaker: Michel started his career as a police officer with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) before transferring to the Canadian Security and Intelligence Service (CSIS). He 
has performed duties as Criminal Investigator, as Intelligence Officer in both Counter Intelligence and Counter Terrorism, 
Now in the private sector, Michel is in demand across all continents to perform Threat and Risk Assessments and security audits.  His work has earned him an enviable 
reputation for his ability to identify pertinent security issues and produce highly specialized results to improve security, not just increase it. He is teaching regularly at various universities in criminology and political 
The Northgate Group Corp.www.tngcorp.com 
sciences. 

6:15 - 7:00 PM: So, you wanna be a pentester? - Adrien de Beaupre

We will discuss the education, background, aptitude, skills, and experience that are often necessary to succeed as a web application penetration tester. 

Speaker: Adrien de Beaupre is a certified SANS instructor and works as an independent consultant in beautiful Ottawa, Ontario. His work experience includes technical instruction, vulnerability assessment, penetration testing, intrusion detection, incident response and forensic analysis. He is a member of the SANS Internet Storm Center (isc.sans.edu). He is actively involved with the information security community, and has been working with SANS since 2000. Adrien holds a variety of certifications including the GXPN, GPEN, GWAPT, GCIH, GCIA, GSEC, CISSP, OPST, and OPSA. When not geeking out breaking things he can be found with his family, or at the dojo.
name: February Meetup

description:
It is time again for Capture the Flag! 

The OWASP Software Security Capture the Flag (CTF for short) will start with a brief lesson on how to find web application software vulnerabilities, followed by a competition for attendees to “hack” our test Web Application.  Individuals or teams will gain points for each vulnerability they find and exploit.  This is a beginner to intermediate level activity. The purpose of this event is to teach about software security in a fun and interactive way.

Logistics:

Bring your laptop with a fully charged battery and a power cable just in case.  

You will need a few tools to play the game. You will receive instructions a couple of weeks before the event with everything you need.

There will be free wi-fi at the Shopify, plus pizza and pop.  The event will be in the same place - Cody's Cafe - 6th Floor.  Be ready to listen, then work in teams or independently to “hack our site".  

Teams must be formed in advance, if you have a team already, that would be great, if you don’t then let us know and we will hook you up with a team (Please email Liam with your team details or to ask to be put on a team: liam dot mcgovern at owasp dot org) 

There will be prizes!  The prizes will be geeky and fun (but not highly valuable).  

Schedule:

5:00 – 5:30: Networking and forming teams (event starts at 6:00 officially)

5:30 – 6:00: Quick overview of the game, and quick tips to help you out.

6:00 – 8:00: Catch the flag

8:00 – 8:30: Results and Networking

Be prepared to have fun and learn at the same time.
name: Capture The Flag

Should you eat beforehand? Yes. We can quickly discuss how we want to tackle food when we meet (e.g. uber eats, brown bag), but for this initial session, we won’t be providing food. However, if you want to bring some snacks to share, please do!

description:
After a summer and fall of discussion, hacking, and civic engagement, we are excited to launch YOWCT and its new format on November 1st. We will meet weekly on Tuesdays: the first night of the month kicks off with presentations and the outlook for the month, subsequent weeks of the month will be focused on hacking.

Agenda for Tuesday November 1st:

6:00pm - 6:30pm Network, eat* (food provided by you)

6:30pm - 7:00pm Welcome + Intros

7:00pm - 7:20pm Speaker: Elizabeth Dubois, Professor at uOttawa

7:20pm - 7:30pm Q&A

7:30pm - 8:20pm Beta recap, pitches and focus for upcoming month

8:20pm - 8:30pm Evening recap/close

Drinks afterwards TBA (optional)

*Food will not be provided / organized, but some suggestions are: Bread and Sons (195 Bank St), Rice and Roll (234 Queen St), and Roast n Brew (83 Bank St)

name: Session #5: Ottawa Civic Tech

description:
We meet weekly on Tuesdays: the first night of the month kicks off with a presentation from a guest speaker and project updates/outlook for the month; the rest of the month will be focused on "hacking" (working on our projects to build civic good).

Agenda for Tuesday December 6th:

6:00pm - 6:30pm Network, eat* (food provided by you)

6:30pm - 7:00pm Welcome + Intros

7:00pm - 7:20pm Guest speaker

7:20pm - 7:30pm Q&A

7:30pm - 7:50pm Project updates

7:50pm - 8:20pm Breakout project group discussions

8:20pm - 8:30pm Close

The featured presenter this month will be Ryan Androsoff from the Government of Canada's Treasury Board Secretariat. Ryan will present on digital government, and run a special breakout group for further discussion.

We'll also have special guests from the Ontario Digital Government team, as part of their monthly “Office Hours” where they meet with the public and hear your thoughts on how to transform government for the digital age.

Le présentateur de cette semaine sera Ryan Androsoff de la Direction du dirigeant principal de l'information au Secrétariat du Conseil du Trésor du Canada. Ryan donnera une présentation sur le gouvernement numérique et facilitera une réunion spéciale en petits groupes afin que nous puissions en discuter davantage.

Nous aurons également des représentants de l'équipe du gouvernement numérique de l'Ontario en fonction de leurs «heures de bureau» mensuelles, où ils rencontrent le public et écoutent vos idées pour comment transformer le gouvernement pour l'ère numérique.

*Food will not be provided / organized, but some suggestions are: Bread and Sons (195 Bank St), Rice and Roll (234 Queen St), and Roast n Brew (83 Bank St)

**If you arrive after 7pm and the front door is locked, please call[masked] and someone will come down! 

Officials from the Chief Information Officer Branch of the Government of Canada’s Treasury Board Secretariat are engaging with stakeholders across Canada on the topic of Digital Government. These discussions are an opportunity to exchange ideas and suggestions to shape a ‘made in Canada’ approach to digital government as they work to improve how digital services are delivered to citizens. The discussions will touch several major themes, including:

– Organizing to deliver digital government, and what we can learn from other jurisdictions and organizations

– Digital talent in government, and how we can bring in world-class digital expertise

– Digital service design and delivery, and how to build services from a user-centred perspective

– Setting the foundations for digital government capacity, building on the federal government’s IT Strategic Plan and Cloud Adoption Strategy


Les fonctionnaires de la Direction du dirigeant principal de l’information du Secrétariat du Conseil du Trésor du gouvernement du Canada mobilisent les principaux intervenants des quatre coins du pays sur le sujet du gouvernement numérique. Ces discussions représentent une occasion d’échanger vos idées et de faire des suggestions afin de forger une approche « fabriquée au Canada » en matière de gouvernement numérique, de même que de proposer une façon d’améliorer la prestation des services numériques à l’endroit des citoyens.  Ces discussions aborderont plusieurs thèmes majeurs, y compris :

– Organisation en vue du déploiement du gouvernement numérique, et ce que nous pouvons apprendre de l’expérience acquise par d’autres organisations et administrations gouvernementales.

– Talent numérique au sein du gouvernement, et comment nous pouvons attirer des compétences spécialisées de classe mondiale.

– Conception et mise en œuvre de services numériques, et comment élaborer des services du point de vue de l’utilisateur.

– Établissement des bases adéquates pour assurer la capacité du gouvernement numérique, et comment miser sur le Plan stratégique de la technologie de l’information et sur la Stratégie d’adoption de l’informatique en nuage du gouvernement du Canada.

description:
We meet weekly on Tuesdays: the first night of the month kicks off with a presentation from a guest speaker and project updates/outlook for the month; the rest of the month will be focused on "hacking" (working on our projects to build civic good).

Agenda for Tuesday, January 10:

6:00pm - 6:30pm Network, eat* (food provided by you)

6:30pm - 7:00pm Welcome + Intros

7:00pm - 7:20pm Guest speaker: Alessandro Alasia, Chief of the Data Exploration and Integration Lab at Statistics Canada

7:20pm - 7:30pm Q&A

7:30pm - 7:50pm Project updates

7:50pm - 8:20pm Breakout project group discussions

8:20pm - 8:30pm Close

Speaker Details:  In the Spring of 2016, Statistics Canada initiated a pilot project aimed at understanding the potential of data crowdsourcing for statistical purposes. The project makes use of OpenStreetMap (OSM) as the open data platform and invites prospective contributors to volunteer georeferenced information on buildings. The pilot project focuses on the Ottawa-Gatineau region but other regions may be added to the project in the future. This seminar will outline some of the preliminary results from the pilot, the lessons learnt so far, as well as the next steps in the implementation of this project.

For more information: http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/statcan-wants-your-help-to-test-the-power-of-crowdsourcing-in-ottawa
how_to_find_us: Use the Elgin Street entrance, where our hosts will meet you to escort you up to Room 2067!

name: Getting started with Data Science and Introduction to Watson Analytics

description:
Registration: 

RSVPing to this meetup is not enough to attend. Please register   ===>>>here<<<===

Data Science Workshop Series (For Beginners) 

After an amazing first event late last year, we are back with our second meetup discussing Data Science topics for beginners. If this is the first time attending, don't worry, there is no pre-requisite!

Abstract:
R is a free, open-source programming language that has gained a lot of traction in recent years among statisticians, researchers, and data scientists alike. But what does a data scientist do and how can R be used as a tool in data science?

In this hands-on meetup, we discuss R fundamentals using the free Data Scientist's Workbench (datascientistworkbench.com). Bring your laptop to this hands-on session!

Presenters:
Dr. Saeed Aghabozorgi (Data Scientist, IBM)

Come learn and socialize! Free pizza and refreshments!

description:
********************************************************************************
Please note that EventBrite registration for this FREE event is required via https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ottawa-women-in-data-science-registration-95676580227 to reserve your spot.
********************************************************************************

In celebration of International Women's Day, the IBM Ottawa Lab would like to invite anyone who is currently working in or aspires to be in Data Science.

Data Science is continuing to evolve as one of the hottest job roles and in-demand career paths for skilled professionals. This meetup will introduce you to the field and provide an excellent opportunity to network with like-minded professionals.

Join us on March 10, 2020, at 4:00-6:00 pm, for an opportunity to learn from the journeys of practising data scientists and to network with others in this exciting field.

Agenda
4:00-4:30 - Registration, refreshments, networking
4:30-5:30 - Presentations and panel discussion
- Each presenter will briefly describe their journey/challenges
- Panel discussion with Q&A
5:30-6:00 - Networking

Attendance is limited, so sign up now to register your spot!

Refreshments will be provided. And did we mention swag for the first 30 attendees?

group.name: Ottawa - Cognitive, AI & Data Science Meetup

name: Ottawa Women in Data Science by IBM

description:
Have you ever wondered if you would have survived the Titanic disaster? Does ticket price impact your odds of survival? What about age and gender? To answer these questions, we will use machine learning (ML) to predict passengers’ survival probabilities. We will guide you through building your first ML pipeline to predict survival probabilities using the original 1912 Titanic passenger dataset (courtesy of Kaggle). We will introduce fundamental ML concepts including: feature engineering, model selection, evaluation, and explainability.

Presenters:
Ali Khanafer is a Senior Data Scientist at IBM. He is currently focused on the applications of NLP and causal inference in business intelligence. He obtained his Ph.D. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

Mohamad Kalil is a Data Scientist at IBM Analytics. He obtained his Ph.D. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from Western University. He is currently focused on infusing AI into Business Intelligence applications to help users uncover patterns hidden in their data and explore and extract data insights with less effort.

Mohammed Mostafa is a senior architect at IBM (STSM). He is leading the effort to infuse AI across the IBM business analytic portfolio. During his career, he has led teams in a variety of areas such as Data Visualization engines, Eclipse Open Source development tools, and Optical Character Recognition.

Original Titanic image courtesy of "By F.G.O. Stuart [masked]) - http://www.uwants.com/viewthread.php?tid=3817223&extra=page%3D1, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=2990792"

group.name: Ottawa - Cognitive, AI & Data Science Meetup

name: Surviving the Titanic the ML way

description:
NOTE: This event has been rescheduled to May 14 (from earlier date of April 30).

What is Watson Studio? In this introductory session, you will learn the answer to that question as well as how to navigate and use Watson Studio.

We will explore the different tools and capabilities of Watson Studio using a variety of business use-cases and datasets, and we will demonstrate how Watson can be used to gather actionable insights and bring value to your business.

Presenter:
Jonathan Messiha is a data scientist at IBM Canada's Machine Learning Hub. He holds a Bachelor of IT from UOIT with a major in Networking and IT Security, and a Master of Management in Artificial Intelligence (MMAI) from Queen's University. Jonathan is an AI enthusiast who enjoys puzzles and solving challenging problems.

group.name: Ottawa - Cognitive, AI & Data Science Meetup

name: Watson Studio - Overview and Demo

description:
*-*-* ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*-*-*
RECOMMENDED PREPARATION TO SET UP YOUR SYSTEM FOR THE HANDS-ON TUTORIAL: Please follow the instructions at https://ibm.box.com/s/z0l42hdk2x2sw05syw7otestso70ledn to create your IBM cloud account and download the dataset.
This prep-work will help you maximize your benefit from the session.
*-*-*-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*-*-*

We will be conducting a hands-on session where attendees can follow along and work with a variety of tools in Watson Studio. It will be a great opportunity for those interested in learning how to use Watson Studio or those who want to advance their knowledge of some of the tools available on Watson. We will provide the business use-case and dataset being demoed so attendees can follow along with the presenter and ask questions.

Note that this is a follow-up to the "Watson Studio: Overview and Demo" meetup on May 14 where we introduced you to the tool and how to get free access to IBM Cloud and Watson Studio. If you missed that session yet are familiar with Watson Studio, then you will be able to leverage this session.

Presenter:
Jonathan Messiha is a data scientist at IBM Canada's Machine Learning Hub. He holds a Bachelor of IT from UOIT with a major in Networking and IT Security, and a Master of Management in Artificial Intelligence (MMAI) from Queen's University. Jonathan is an AI enthusiast who enjoys puzzles and solving challenging problems.

group.name: Ottawa - Cognitive, AI & Data Science Meetup

name: Watson Studio - Hands-on Tutorial

description:
NOTE: This event has been rescheduled to Jul 30 (from earlier date of Jul 2).

With IBM Cognos Analytics, you can explore your data or investigate visualization from a dashboard or story. As you work, contextual recommendations and advanced analytics insights will be surfaced in a subtle way, so as not to intrude. Take advantage of advanced analytics normally available only in data science tools. You won’t be bothered with positioning widgets or fancy formatting. Just work away, and when you want to present your insights, simply copy your visualizations to a story or dashboard.
This workshop introduces you to some of the newest capabilities included in IBM Cognos Analytics, Data Exploration, which utilizes augmented intelligence to accelerate the time to value in finding insights hidden deep within your data, including: upload data sources to explore; discover relationships in your data; surface insights to begin your analysis; identify patterns and key drivers.

Presenter:
Dennis Buttera - Education Lead, Center for Advanced Studies, IBM Canada Lab
As Education Lead, Dennis collaborates with a global network of leading institutions to provide guidance to design and implement capability-based data science and analytics courses across a full spectrum from introductory electives to specialized degree programs and advanced degrees - institutions are encouraged to share this curriculum and learning objects.

group.name: Ottawa - Cognitive, AI & Data Science Meetup

name: Exploration with Cognos Analytics

description:
It is recommended that you register at this Webex link ahead of time to receive a calendar invite and reminder. https://ibm.webex.com/ibm/j.php?RGID=r13153bf39334094f7c5afe1858463cac
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Startup with IBM. Build. Scale. Win. As a start-up, learn how to leverage IBM's Start-Up program and the Ottawa Machine Learning Hub.

With IBM’s scalable solutions, you can revolutionize your build. Use your free $120,000 IBM Cloud credits to access more than 130 unparalleled services.

With the IBM Ottawa Machine Learning Hub, you can leverage AI and ML expertise at no cost to build models towards better business outcomes.

Put your business on the path to transformative growth. Disrupt your industry with IBM. We'll show you how.

Presenters:
Lee Bowie, Technology Evangelist, Innovation and Government Affairs, IBM Canada from Ottawa, Ontario
Lee has decades of experience as a software developer and IT architect in the public and private sectors. He has been a DevOps Coach in IBM Labs, worked as a Cloud Advisor as part of an elite global team of consultants and now is a Technology Evangelist helping startups exploit the Cloud and grow their business.
He co-hosts "The Classic Rock Album by Album" podcast and is a rock star to about 10 people as the leader of the "Lee Bowie Band".

Sonia Singh, Data and AI Engagement Program Manager for the IBM Ottawa Lab
Sonia is currently involved with the IBM Data Science Elite team and is managing the Ottawa ML Hub. She has a degree in Computer Science, with certifications in Project Management and Data Science. Her experience includes software development, user interface design, customer research, people management, project management, operations management, and data science. Her IBM tenure of 14+ years includes a Corporate Service Corps (CSC) assignment in Malaysia, which provides high-performing IBMers with quality leadership development.

group.name: Ottawa - Cognitive, AI & Data Science Meetup

name: Leveraging IBM's Start-Up Program and Ottawa Machine Learning Hub
